Departments rarely are given the autonomy to lead or run themselves, instead having unit heads butt in and make decisions when they don't know departmental processes. review_title: IU is NOT the greatest place to work in Indiana
pros: Good health benefits, decent time off
cons:
Everyone making less that 6 figures is underpaid, have to fight tooth and nail to get any remote work, bloated middle management, pretending Covid no longer exists, pretending that everything they do is about students while it's actually just about money, etc....

IU doesn't care about you unless you're making 6 figures or are a student. They send out plenty of propaganda trying to convince you they care, but their actions speak much louder than their words. They forced everyone to go back to campus after we all worked remotely for over a year, and there was little flexibility with allowing continuation of remote work. The new president was hand-picked by one trustee (no longer there) and was chosen in a very concerning manner (decision made behind closed doors, threw out initial search party's choices, etc...there is an article written by an IU instructor that explains this in-depth). There are meetings happening with this new president where she puts everyone's cell phones into a black bag and forbids the presence of pen and paper. IU is currently laying off staff members across all campuses for the sake of their budgets while spending money on new statues, buildings, unnecessary events, and upper-management. One example of this was the unveiling of a $60,000 jaguar statue on the IUPUI campus earlier in 2021 for "campus beautification", which was actually ready much sooner but kept hidden during 2020 because they didn't want to look bad putting up a statue worth nearly twice my salary in the middle of a pandemic. IU constantly pushes advisors to do more for student retention while refusing to let them work remotely, criminally underpaying them, and laying them off because the "data" said they were no longer useful. Oh, and did I mention that IU consistently brags about IU being the safest place to be during Covid while cases around the world skyrocket and IU no longer offers asymptomatic testing or boosters? 

There are so many other things I could discuss here, but the bottom line is this: don't work for IU. It's not worth it.

review_title: Job benefits and salaries are lacking
pros: Job security, culture, campus life, mission, work/life balance, PTO
cons:
IU once had the best benefits in the area, but every year they increase health insurance premiums and raise our deductibles. 
Parking costs go up every year. Staff have to pay to park on campus, and there aren't enough spaces for everyone, so finding a space becomes a real challenge, and often makes us late for work. They've eliminated many of the "cheaper" parking lots, so we're all forced to buy the premium, expensive, parking permits.
But our "cost of living" increases never meet the rate of inflation, and actual merit-based raises are extremely difficult to get. Salaries are already below market range. So the longer you work at IU, the less money you make. It used to be that our benefits made up for our low salaries, but that's no longer the case.

We just hit record enrollment, but the staff are never compensated for their hard work, the money always goes to upper administration.

Staff are made to feel very low-priority, we're here to do whatever the faculty want, regardless of our professional advice and experience. IU is very top-down, and staff are at the very bottom. It's demoralizing.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Bloomington, IN
pros: Good retirement, staff are great to work with though some faculty can be difficult.
cons: Being in the middle space of working in research but not as tenure-track faculty isn't ideal here. There are no raises (other than modest cost of living adjustments every 1-3 years) even if your performance is strong, unless you go through what is equivalent to a tenure process to be promoted. Unless you are base funded, you are also going to be scrambling to get your salary covered with grant funding. Basically, it's the stress of research focused tenure-track work minus the security of actually being base-funded and tenure-track.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros:
Unlike soft science graduate programs, most hard science graduate programs offer to pay for tuition, a stipend to live on (if you teach as a TA or are supported by a grant as an RA), and pretty good health insurance. 

Many of the perks that undergraduates get as students we do as well, e.g., able to ride the bus for free, use the campus gym for free.

Most of the time we're offered better parking options than undergrads, though it is rather expensive. 

Depending on your advisor, you can take about 3-4 weeks of vacation a year. Sick days are not so strict.
cons:
Depending on your Ph.D. advisor (and your lab culture, lab mates, etc), your time here could be hell or somewhat fun. Matching well with your advisor seems to be the most important.

Grad students (STEM anyway) are expected to work 60-80 hour weeks for less than $25k/year. This is essentially slave labor for how ridiculously qualified we are as PhD-level chemists. We drive the research (and flow of money) in these research institutions and we're treated like nothing sometimes, emotionally abused, etc. 

Our program here is pretty good (rankings-wise) but they do a poor job preparing your for an industry job (or any job outside of academia), unless you major in organic or analytical chemistry, which is where all of the jobs are these days. Just a heads up. Network from day one, because academic professors usually know zero contacts in industry.

review_title: Great university and community; poor leadership
pros:
- IU is a terrific university and extremely important to the state of Indiana.
- Bloomington is one of the very best college towns in the country. Lots to do and the people generally are wonderful
- The staff colleagues are a close-knit group and the day-to-day work environment is positive.
- The benefits are outstanding. A lot of vacation time, good health care coverage, generous retirement.
cons:
- The president is an ego-driven autocrat who cares more about his legacy than the long-term success of the university. He provides little actual leadership and is more concerned that he get credit for IU's success and that he get to do what interests him (such as international travel) than doing the hard work to push the university forward.

- Faculty morale is low and the university is losing good people as result of a general feeling that administration doesn't care as much about the scholarly mission of the university as it does about erecting new buildings. Academic changes are forced upon faculty with little chance for input and without necessary resources to make them work properly.

- Upward mobility is limited because succession planning is non-existent.

- Too much time is spent pursuing work that isn't critical to the university's mission.

review_title: Great Starter Job to Move on to Better Job
pros:
PTO can be rolled to next year.  Great opportunity to learn for someone who doesn't have the qualifications for skilled IT job.  403B if you can stay over 3 years.  Work from home if IT job allows .

Take the 3 years to build your resume and learn.
cons:
Low pay and work around the clock -  even if skilled in IT position forces job burnout for high skilled employees who are blamed for mistakes unrelated to them or due to heavy workload. 

 Lack of training course funding while upper management attends junkets in Vegas, Europe etc.

 Favoritism in IT pay - some are making 10-15thousand  more and working less.  The trick is do not volunteer for anything - if you do and mess up you will be blamed for everything.  Those who don't speak up are quietly given raises - check the Indiana public salary site.    Managers salaries are extremely high in comparison to other employees and are even higher than managers in outside IT management.  Jumps from 92000 a year to over 400000.  While employees wages are kept low.  Extreme favoritism and unfavorable blame game environment.  Too many meetings and chit chat in them for employees actually working to get their job done.  Some jobs require 24x7 support and they mean it - if you don't work it or answer phone you will hear the wrath about it.  Remember don't volunteer for anything.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros: IU and UITS is a good place to work. Typically the work environment is pretty lax, however, there are newer higher-ups who want to change that. But for now you can still operate on flex time, stroll in before 9, leave a little early, etc. There is enough work to keep you busy, and plenty of projects for those who want more of a challenge. You can be given opportunities to lead if you show an aptitude for learning and accepting responsibility. Everyone will complain about the benefits and escalating health premiums, and I can get behind that, but overall things are not that bad, and a lot better than many other employers. There are numerous advancement opportunities at IU. UITS is a large organization, so IT personnel can try new positions and retain their benefits and whatnot.
cons: Pay isn't as good as it should/could be, and don't expect more than 1.5-2.5% a year. The best way to earn more money is to change jobs every few years, or leave IU and return. Some in upper management are making poor decisions, affecting the morale and future of IU, and ultimately leaving things worse off than when they started.
