review_title: Cream and Crimson Graduate Student Experience
pros:
The best reason is the ability to go to sporting events, concerts at the music school, attend shows at the Indiana University Auditorium, and have all the resources and opportunities that exist at a large state university available. 

Bloomington is a decent town, and has a great school district if you have children. There are awesome restaurants and a decent night life scene separate from undergraduate students.

The bus system is good. The city of Bloomington has a reciprocal agreement with IU so that students, faculty and staff can use their IU IDs to ride city buses for free (covered by the student transportation fee).
cons:
Bloomington is a small town, and very white. While it isn't far, Indianapolis is an hour plus drive on a state road with some slow areas and a number of police cars.

People look at you as if you have two heads if you are not a huge Hoosiers fan.

The graduate students have some of the lowest compensation structures in the Big Ten. 

RCM budgeting is taken to the extreme. There is little to no reciprocity, and there is red tape at every turn. 

The trustees wield an inordinate amount of power.

Some facilities are falling apart; some needs are completely ignored, and "temporary office space" is temporary in name only for many departments.

pros: Very accommodating with your schedule and pay above minimum wage.
cons: Hours are a bit odd

job_title: Early Childhood Teacher's Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros:
Location on campus
Schedule adaptable to semester schedule
Empowering community of caregivers
cons:
Steep learning curve
30 hour maximum

job_title: College and Career Coach in Bloomington, IN
pros: Working Environment; Academic; Talent ;Mission
cons: No major cons at this time

pros: Flexible schedule, very friendly staff
cons: Late hours, few weekly hours

pros: Flexible schedule, student friendly, passionate staff
cons: not a lot of hours

pros: this is such a great place
cons: I think there are better places

pros: Ability to work while pursuing a degree.
cons: Complete disregard for employee health and wellness. No consideration of employee input. Dishonest description of advancement opportunities. Low salary compared to industry average.

pros:
professional development 
a small, family friendly town 
cost of living is not as high compared to other places
cons:
small town -- can be boring 
pay is not as great 
there is a disconnect between academics and the staff  -- even more so between the whole university community and the local folk. 
classes are hit or miss. this is a research university so profs are kept for the ability to research and not teach. you can be stuck with a professor who has no knowledge of teaching methods. at times  professors can be intimidating both towards their students and the staff -- i have been on both sides;

pros:
Tuition Reimbursement
Excellent Time Off - starts with 30 days for professional staff!
EXCELLENT retirement contributions - They have the best contributions to a 401B that I've ever heard of
-All their benefit information is available on their website and can be accessed by anyone - very helpful when determining benefits of working here
Great health benefits...my premiums aren't even $20 a month for my family!
cons:
salary - HOWEVER, the salary may sound low, but when you calculate what they contribute to your retirement on top of how much you save in healthcare coverage, I took a position here that was thousands less than a previous job, but it actually worked out that I'm making more becuase of how much less is deducted from my pay for healthcare and retirement savings....it really is a better overall salary package.
parking - once you have a pass you're good to go, but you may be on a waiting list for a while for a parking permit that's close and convenient to your office.  regardless, you will get a pass when you work here...it's just a matter of how far you'll have to walk to make it to your building.

review_title: I felt that I was able to make a significant contribution here.
pros: (Note: I was a student hourly employee who worked for several smaller departments within the university, not the university at large.)  The work environment was incredibly friendly and open.  Most important to me--there were plenty of opportunities and lots of freedom for me to take on new projects.  For example, when one of the groups where I worked was holding a workshop, I offered to develop a registration system, and they allowed me to.  As a result, I was able to learn about programming while on the job.  I was also able to take on a variety of other tasks (like handling some product orders, processing travel reimbursements, etc.), while not directly related to my career, allowed me to learn how larger organizations work.
cons: Since I was a student hourly, I didn't receive any benefits, like paid time off.  My supervisors were always very flexible with when I scheduled time off, however.

pros: Health benefits were good at least
cons: Pay, parking, no breaks! Overworked

review_title: Okay...depending on who your manager is.
pros: If you live on campus, it's great. It's close to your dorm room and the pay isn't that bad. If you want to do minimal work, train to be a cashier.
cons:
The process for becoming a student supervisor is terrible. Actually, there is no process. You have to suck up to the existing student supervisors and party with them. If you have a different friend group and don't want to associate with them, then good luck. The manager (a non-student who runs everything) is practically controlled by these students. The people who'd actually be good supervisors and actually do their work are unnoticed, because they aren't chatting with the existing student supervisors. 

I had to train student supervisors on how to do their job every day I worked. I often had to take on the role of supervisor because they had no idea what to do.

review_title: Great resume builder for advising/mentoring careers, in a supportive, engaging environment
pros: You get to reflect on your experiences abroad, and therefore develop your own reasoning for why studying abroad is useful for personal and professional growth. The advisors and staff are supportive and train you very well. The schedule is very flexible since all of the peer counselors are students, and so the ability to work shifts in between classes or after them is a great aspect of the position. Also, you don't have to work weekends, but might work some evenings.
cons: There are a number of peer counselors, so if you're looking for a lot of income to pay for rent or other higher costs of living, then it's not going to fulfill your fiscal needs. However, since you don't work weekends, or most evenings you could still get another part time job and not feel more overworked than you would just working a serving or retail job.

pros: I worked as a student manager at IU Auditorium during Undergrad, and it was easily the best  on-campus job to have as a student. We were given independence because we were trusted and valued as employees. What started as a volunteer position that I worked 12 hours a semester eventually became a part-time job that I could go to whenever something needed to be done for an event. There was a lot of opportunities for promotions as meeting famous people who walked through our doors. The coworkers were the bests people you could imagine working with and we all had an appreciation for the Auditorium.
cons: There was sometimes too much pressure from admin staff to get things done immediately, when we were all full-time students. The way the rates were set up were not good. The university kept raising minimum wage, but the Auditorium had a cap with how much part-time employees could make, which was not raised. I reached the cap three semesters before I graduated, so I never received the raises others received  each semester.

review_title: Student Job great for students, not for people who take jobs seriously
pros: Worked as a student so the main reason to keep working there is because of the excellent hours for students. The pay was also pretty good. I was getting $7 an hour to sit in a computer lab and do nothing most of the time, though I had to be there in case of a computer breaking or printer jamming or whatnot.
cons: Management is also compiled by students who are just learning to work and are all on some sort of power trip. Although I worked there for 3 years straight, I NEVER got the pay raise I deserved that other people got after they completed one semester of work. I had to ask for it, multiple times. Also, some of the student managers took their job too seriously and got people fired for putting a smiley face on the company intranet chat.

job_title: Support Center Consultant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Generally I have been treated well in this position by the people I work with. There is not a lot of interaction between coworkers since we mainly interact with clients. Overall the environment is pleasant and people generally support one another. UITS usually hires employees from within, so almost everyone working there has provided tier-one support.
cons: You are expected to work pretty much the whole time you are on your shift. If you are not answering phone calls, you need to be answering emails. It can get exhausting on longer shifts and policies are changing pretty frequently, so it can be difficult to keep up with what management is doing as a part-time worker.

review_title: Wonderful place to work if you can avoid the politics
pros: Overall quality of employees is excellent.  Working conditions are pleasant.  Salary is below average, but acceptable.  Very good benefits package.  Definite family atmosphere among colleagues at similar levels.
cons: Initial training when assuming position is non-existent.  Professional development opportunities provided, but avoided by top management.  Support and training from supervisor is variable, and may focus on supervisor's personal agenda rather than job requirements.  Performance evaluations may be based entirely on politics and ignore actual job performance.  Corrective measures are sometimes vague or not attainable, e.g. demonstrate that you are a lifelong learner within the next 30 days.

pros:
Not all AI-ships are alike. I believe some AIs have lots of teaching responsibilities, mine have been largely supportive. I am an out–of–state MS student doing part–time AI work as part of my financial aid. I am not doing PhD or Tenure track / teaching classes alone.

Advisors and professors I've worked for have been flexible and understanding of circumstances, and will tend to have your back when students want to dispute grades.
Some classes have very engaged and eager students that make it rewarding (…inverse is also sometimes true).
cons:
Clocking in and out is a ritual that has been enforced more strongly since I've started. Otherwise it's been fairly agreeable.
Sometimes the large number of appointments and sizes of class enrollments might mean an AI is assigned to a course they have little knowledge or experience with, but because of the numbers that may not be avoidable. This may not be true with all schools/departments.

review_title: OK if you're fine with working for a Soviet bureaucracy
job_title: Systems Programmer Analyst in Bloomington, IN
pros:
Plentiful time off

flexible hours

Good state retirement benefits

Tuition disbursement
cons:
1-2% raises. 

Staff are lowest on the totem pole. 

University has no qualms about screwing employees who worked hard for 26 years. Middle management is good but McRobbie will always do whatever the trustees say. the trustees have no sense of what things are like outside of board rooms, so you can imagine that as a ground level employee you will periodically get utterly moronic dictats from on high that no one had the will to question. 

Holcomb as governor means even less state funding than before, especially with STEM fetishism, so just accept your pay will barely track cost of living increases. You will love the people in the trenches with you, but be mindful that they are indeed trenches.

review_title: Good place to work if schedule flexibility is your number one concern
job_title: Lab Technician TE07 in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Lots of flexibility in schedule and work week/day.  In this position I am allowed to work abbreviated work weeks, or to alter my hours on a day to day basis to meet my personal needs.  This is especially helpful if you have small children or a lot of family obligations
cons: Pay is not very good for this level and no room to move up.  I have been here for two years and there is no chance for improvement, nor am I encouraged to learn new skills.  I would liken the kind of work I do a lot of the time to being a line worker at a factory.  If you are just looking for job it's ok, but it doesn't make a good career.

pros: Great healthcare. There is a pedagogy seminar and support for first-time instructors and yearly teaching awards to recognize graduate student achievements. The English Department specifically is awesome and advocates for its graduate students.
cons: The pay (stipend) is not great for the hours we put in and for the importance of the service we provide to the university. Most graduate students also need to find part time jobs. If summer teaching were guaranteed, the pay would be more manageable year round, but saving for the summer on a stipend that is less than $20k when you are also expected to do research is difficult. A large chunk of that stipend is taken away for university fees ($2k a year).

review_title: Being an AI doesn't pay well but it can be useful
pros: Get experience teaching and mentoring students, learn more about your subject area by teaching it, if you only have to teach one class it's not so much work for the money
cons: low salary (depends on department), not as low an amount of extra work as a fellowship, students can be a hassle sometimes

pros: People are nice, the work is worthwhile, and there is definitely job security.
cons: Salaries are LOW... about half of what other Big Ten schools pay for the exact same job.  As a result, everyone who works at IU is a local of Bloomington, and there is rampant nepotism in getting jobs.  It's one of the whitest places I've ever worked as a result, very little diversity in the staff, and those who do come from places other than Bloomington do not stay.

review_title: Lots of flexibility, not much mentoring or involvement in the IU community
job_title: Adjunct Instructor (South Bend, History/Philosophy Department ) in South Bend, IN
pros:
- Lots of freedom: there are no meetings to attend, I get to choose my own books for my courses, and there are pretty much no controls on how I teach.
- Office space: Nice office space, and I share an office with only one other person.
- Flexibility in scheduling: Department chair has always been quite accommodating about working with my preferred schedule
cons:
- The lack of meetings and lack of constraints is great in some ways, but it also means there is really no mentoring, and I feel rather unconnected with my department and with the IU community in general.
- I don't envision any possibility for a full-time position here--I'm restricted to part time only.

pros:
Flexibility in work method and hours.  Most professors don't expect much of you so if you put in any effort it will become apparent.  Helped me to get a higher paying assistant-ship in another school. 

Kelly is the best paid school, so if you can, try to work there.  Even if you are in a different field, they have so many students that they really just need graders.
cons: You are very limited in the number of hours you can work, expect annoying emails if you miss a punch.  Time clock system is horribly designed.

review_title: The benefits of working for IU are very good and the health insurance plans are great including an HSA account as well.
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Job security.  The work life balance is good and you accrue enough time off and personal time that it is always available to use when needed.  Hours can be flexible depending on who you work for.
cons: No room for growth unless you have a master's degree.  Once you are in a position there, it is very difficult to move to another department unless you know someone.  The jobs are very political and most often to get ahead you need to be connected.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Bloomington, IN
pros:
Open and accepting atmosphere on campus
Lots of opportunities for personal enrichment
Friendly people
Good health benefits
cons: Annoying system for getting paid (in all fairness, probably similar to how all universities pay their students/employess). As a PhD student/Research Associate/Teaching Assistant every semester I was getting paid by a different department pretty much each semester, which resulted in being pair varying amounts per month each semester, and it could be difficult to get information about exactly when and how much I was going to be receiving some months, especially months where pay days fell around the holidays (Christmas and Thanksgiving) or over the summer.

pros: College town, likely to have educated coworkers. Employment varies greatly. It is entirely possible to land a decent job with good compensation and work-life balance.
cons: It is possible to land a job where micromanagement rules. Some positions have 4-5 quite visible supervisors. It feels like there are more managers than workers, with no tangible results in a long time. Insufficient training provided. No incentive for managers to value workers. On average, very low pay, with benefits diminishing over the years. Management pay exemplifies the rest of the U.S., where it is disproportionately heavy on top, and not making a living wage at the bottom. Disparity between self-promotion ("values") and actual actions.

review_title: The PhD life in Indiana University
pros:
1. Very large and beautiful campus
2. Very good international service
3. Open and good academic environment
4. helpful advisor
5. international environment and collaboration
cons:
1. The ranking of the university is not very high
2. It is located in a small town so you don't have many access to big city
3. You need to go to another city Indianapolis to take the flight so it is not convenient
4. The salary is not very high

pros: They try really hard to provide the best benefits they can. Campus located in tough, run down area (Gary) so they try to make the workplace environment/ campus very nice, pleasant to be engaged in. Campus itself small but very worker friendly. Faculty are treated respectfully by administrative staff.
cons: Like many universities today, faculty have only a semblance of power and archaic 'management' structures to have a impact on the campus decision-making. Its as if the administrative executive allows faculty to believe they have power to change management decisions, but not really so. Executive management makes tons more money than faculty who should be the core value capital of any university. Executive management also knows they wield more power and do so at will, abet remaining 'respectful' on the face to faculty.

review_title: Positive Work Environment for Non-Faculty Staff
pros: Indiana University is a great place to work as a University Division academic advisor. Advising management and colleagues are collegial and supportive. Most staff working in offices across  campus are supportive and professional as well. There are many opportunities for professional development and support from supervisors and campus organizations.  Advising at Indiana University is student centered and most advising staff forward that mission.
cons: The student rosters are very large and advisors have many non-student advising responsibilities to attend to in addition to student appointments and emails. Managing the workload can be challenging during the course registration period of the summer.

pros:
Close to 80/90 highway corridor
May be a good value for students
cons:
This is a poorly managed campus in the  campus system. While the new chancellor seems to be wanting to improve the campus retention and recruitment effort, the executive council who are long time staff members won't let him. There is a lot of turnover and nepotism. Some of the rejects from the steel Mills have ended up here especially in IT. Those who are  not seen as conforming to the group think are managed out. Information Technology Leadership is poor and needs to be re-evaluated in terms of content, vision, diversity, skill and ethics. 
If they see you work hard and won't tolerate bullying, out the door you go.
Other issues-
Resource starved, no adequate work spaces
Poor training  opportunities
Poor oversight of senior management 
Race relations is very poor.

pros: The faculty and professional staff include many wonderful, dedicated people. The surrounding community (at least in Bloomington) is special. In many departments, this is a great place to work. The university is an accepting place for many kinds of individuals.
cons: Bureaucracy can be crushing at times. The current president is out of touch, extravagant and ego-driven. At higher-levels the pay for similar jobs can vary widely. Aside from an excellent provost, too few women have reached high ranks within the university.

review_title: Peer Counselor at the IU Office of Overseas Study
pros: I enjoyed working in a place where everyone had an interest in going abroad and discovering the world. I felt fulfilled as I helped other students begin the process to study abroad and explore another culture. I also improved my public speaking skills as we regularly did presentations in front of audiences ranging from 10 up to 100. In addition, I got to help create the new website for the office by checking it for any glitches during the final editing phase.
cons: The least interesting part was working at the information booths around campus. Not many people want to stop by, so that gives a bit too much free time sometimes. It also gets a little slow at the office during the off season.

pros: Work/career stability. Health care is serious ups and downs in the current economic climate, so as an organization, leadership is extremely focused in bringing management style into the 21st century and beyond. I really appreciate the change in tone of leadership, and management style.
cons: From my department view, there's a serious lack of real vision. Management is still working to be less secretive and more inclusive with all its employees. Still lots of "clubs" and "cliques" which unfortunately, fails to recognize and promote those with real talent to offer. My department has way more leadership turn over than employee turn over, which is odd.

review_title: A postdoctoral position at IU can be a great stepping stone in your career.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Bloomington, IN
pros: Working with leaders in various fields has been a great growth and learning experience.  And, working with bright students with fresh ideas has been wonderful.  Additionally, my position was very flexible when dealing with time-off for home/family/health issues.
cons:
Support staff turnover seemed to be high.  So, things like travel arrangements for conferences, etc. end up best being done by yourself, even though this takes away from your time to do useful research.

This is not a criticism of IU specifically, but of academia in general: The amount of time spent writing proposals to get funding seems disproportionate to the benefit.

review_title: Plan and execute new media and social media initiatives for Indiana University Recreational Sports.
pros: The thing I like the most about working at Indiana University Recreational Sports was the culture that I encountered therein. The hiring process is such that they ensure that the people they are hiring have the type of personality that well compliments the company culture. And by this I mean that the culture within the organization is one that encourages communication, respect, and creativity.
cons: The cons of working for Indiana University, or more specifically, for Indiana University Recreational Sports, is that unfortunately the pay wasn't the greatest.

pros:
I enjoy working as a staff scientist in a scientific department. The quality of facilities varies a bit department-wide, but my building and office has some of the nicest facilities on campus. All grad students, faculty, and staff have access to high-performance computing resources on campus free of charge, which is a pretty big deal compared to other places I've worked.

On top of all that, Bloomington is a wonderful place to live, has a lot of great dining options close to campus, and a very nice famer's market.
cons: Honestly, the biggest complaint I have is that the department mailing list is bombarded by frequent emails of a social nature that have nothing to do with science or the department's interests. It's very unprofessional and pretty annoying.

review_title: Former Graduate Worker in Media School
pros: Some great faculty, good sense of community fostered by other grad students
cons:
The pay is low, and change is slow! 

I appreciate that IU has full funding options for their graduate degrees in the Media School, and I do not regret attending. But $15,000 per year is not a living wage, especially since the university requires students to pay up to 15 percent of it back in fees. Graduate students teach 30 percent of classes at IU. At the very least, graduate fees should be eliminated and we should be able to afford rent and health care. This is why academia struggles with racial and socioeconomic diversity: grad school is too expensive a ladder for most people to take a chance on climbing.

review_title: Excellent benefits and work/life balance, but friction between some positions creates stress
job_title: Clinical Research Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: 30 days of PTO starting, with flexibility of schedule, good work life balance, and the opportunity to work from home are major pros.
cons: The voluntary turnover for my position in my department is high compared to others in the office due to a number of factors such as relative salary and crippling work load. There is friction between the research nurse and CRS positions for a few reasons that has existed for years and is frequently taken to management without success.

review_title: IUPUI is a good place to work
pros: The best reasons to work at IUPUI are the people I work with are great and the environment is very laid back.  When I come into work, my lab mates greet me happily and are ready to work to solve the problems necessary to achieve our current goals.  We are able to make our own schedule which is great because it allows us to come and go as we please as long as we get our work done and attend the weekly meetings.
cons: The downsides of working at IUPUI are that sometimes you can not get management to work with you or provide enough attention for your needs.

review_title: A solid community when you know the right people.  A joke when you don't. (UITS)
job_title: regionaler Projektleiter / Planer in Bloomington, IN
pros: Very open and purpose driven team is waiting for you if you do the right networking.  Your input matters and things will change if you make a good enough case for it.  Outsourcing storage and accounts to 3rd parties a major win.  Always another rung on the ladder within reach.
cons: Amoral culture at CIB can get more than a little annoying.  Touting green policies but still having all the lights, ac/heat, and coal power of a small town is laughable.  Coke and sodexo (read: no free food/pseudo-evil contributions).  Dog and pony committees and busy work all too common.

review_title: Dining Hall Server - The Restaurants at Woodland
job_title: Food Court Server in Bloomington, IN
pros: Able to schedule around classes, decent pay considering the level of work, awesome people to work with (if they know what they're doing), different stuff to do almost each shift.
cons: Once you're scheduled for the semester, it's difficult to adjust the schedule, so plan ahead. You can get people to cover your shift if you're lucky, but overall you'll have a rough time. The politics in the workplace between different positions can grow tense as the semesters go on. Lack of specific training before being put on the job means you'll be learning as you're serving food.

pros: I was given a lot of responsibility, learned a lot about research lab techniques and equipment and they were very invested in teaching undergrads.  I had an awesome PI who was very invested in my development as a researcher so I was very lucky.  A lot will depend on the PI
cons: I don't really have anything bad to say about the position.  I really liked the set up and felt that the compensation and work were very fair but it will really depend on who you work for.

review_title: I had a respectful work relationship.
pros:
My supervisor may not have had much supervisory/management experience, but he made me it comfortable for me to focus on the projects together.
As a part-time and a student employee, the schedule was flexible and I could put hours whenever I could.
I could partake in a related, but on the side, projects and I was not restricted.
cons:
There was minimal interaction among the staff so we didn't get to know each other - but it was also related to the type of job.
Long hours at computer - also was related to the type of job.

review_title: friendly people but not much room to grow
pros: Interesting colleagues and good facilities.  Reasonable work/life balance.  Once you have a job you can usually work it as long as you want; job security is pretty good.  The town of Bloomington is dynamic and a good place for a young family.
cons: Advancement is very difficult.  Positions are stratified and there's not much room for growth.  The University dominates the town and community and so it tends to be arrogant in its dealings with staff; people have few alternatives if you want to remain in Bloomington.  Compensation, unless you're working at the highest administrative or academic levels, does not seem to be very competitive.

review_title: IU Campus Bus is one of the greatest part-time jobs available in Bloomington, IN.
pros: The management and supervisory staff was amazing.  They were extremely approachable and cared about employee's personal lives and situations.  The job was also fun because you did not have a supervisor constantly looking over your shoulder while you were working.  You could jump in the bus, put on your music, and just drive and talk to people for hours.
cons: Working for a major university, there is a lot of red tape, and change takes a long time.

review_title: If you're a tenured professor= bank, anything else = dirt.
pros: Indian University is nestled in my beautiful home town of Bloomington IN. Great culture, great food, small town feel while generally having everything you nee/ want (including a HUGE disparity from the wealthiest to the normal "townies" = non-student here on Mommy and Daddy's buck)
cons: IU has a large body of ready and willing young students are aren't in much of a position to demand benefits or a better paying job, or just don't know how to do such a thing, so IU gets away with paying their people crap. Some positions have great benefits, especially if you have a family, but mostly they keep you just under full time so they don't have to give you any.

pros: Benefits were great. Medical, dental vision and retirement were the only reasons I could get out of bed and force myself to go to work each day. I met a few kind, hard working individuals along the way but benefits were the reason I held on as long as I did.
cons: My boss was incompetent and mentally abusive. Many of her peers recognized she was bad news but she remained employed to run amock. The culture is one that tolerates allowing faculty to mistreat staff and I wanted no parts of that.

review_title: GlobalNOC System Engineer at Indiana University
pros: The Systems group is very collaborative and cooperative. People ask lots of questions every day and those that know the answers respond. There is constant striving to do things better.  There is a lot to learn but everyone realizes it takes time. You don't have to know it all when you arrive. The vacation time and retirement benefits are great.
cons: There is some on-boarding, but most of what you learn, you pick up in bits and pieces as you work on tickets (with help).  You do both systems administration-type work as well as programming; that may be a pro or con, depending on the person.

pros: Great benefits....as long as you are professional staff and work at the university level.
cons: University level is out-of-touch with campus level benefits and the radical difference between professional staff and support staff. Raises are "across the board" rather than based on merit, which means that longevity means more pay, not ability and a good work ethic. It's a very top-heavy work environment with those who run things patting themselves on the back.

review_title: Indiana University is an excellent place to further one's career.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Bloomington, IN
pros: Excellent work-life balance, great benefits package.
cons: Relatively low-paying for position/education level. The experience that you have as an employee is largely determined by the personality of your supervisor if you are in academic research. if you have a good boss, things are great. If you have a bad boss, you are left with little to no recourse, but this is generally true of academia as a whole.

review_title: Conflict is common between and within schools
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Bend, IN
pros: Great location to benefit from a small town atmosphere while within easy reach of a major metropolitan area (Chicago). Much opportunity to make a difference in the lives of first-generation or inadequately prepared students who seek a better life after graduation than their parents have enjoyed.
cons: Infighting and gamesmanship over declining resources as enrollment and student retention rates decline. Equity concerns due to the disparity between liberal arts and professional school salaries create a culture of protectionism and cronyism at the expense of student support. Like many higher education institutions, IUSB is struggling to manage the opposing trends of declining student satisfaction and the need to raise academic rigor to meet employer demands.

review_title: A satisfying job for recent graduates or entry level IT Training
pros: Flexible schedules, Intellectual knowledge base, Software resources, Current computing technology offered for work purposes, Comfortable & calm work environment, Professional staff who are very informative and helpful (many who are underpaid for their skill sets).
cons: Limited current job openings for entry level job seekers as the economy recovers, and no yearly or semester based hourly rate increases for specific position.

pros: Diverse culture of academic growth with fee remission benefits that provides personal satisfaction and opportunity to advance career.
cons: Extremely competitive at times for job advancement.  Some units have political culture staff must work through and favoritism.  Low annual increases and doesn’t usually cover increased cost of living. Paying to park is expensive and often hard to park.

pros: Plenty of latitude to explore and develop solutions for research projects. Mostly relaxed atmosphere. Hands-off managerial style. Great insurance benefits. Generous PTO offerings.
cons: Advancement is very limited. Salary is mediocre. Results-driven deadlines can cause punctuations of extremely high stress. Budgets constrain even baseline hardware and software necessary to achieve results of significance. Projects are often passed along to implement without appropriate viability reviews. Expect bureaucracy and regulations to hinder equipment acquisition and reasonable research practices.

job_title: Internet Marketing Specialist in Bloomington, IN
pros: The work/life balance in three positions I've had at IU was quite good. It was easy to leave work at work and separate it from my personal life. Benefits, especially insurance, are amazing.
cons: Positions pay significantly less than what one could reasonably expect and there is no room for negotiation as salaries are slotted in advance. Little opportunity for salary growth beyond sub-cost of living increases.

pros: Decent pay, and the hours are extremely flexible. Your assigned professor usually makes an effort to work around your schedule with classes and Office Hours.
cons:
The work picks up when you are extremely busy as well. You spend most of the time doing tedious work such as grading and general class supervision.

The work you do or the experience you have dramatically will change depending on whom you are assigned. More so than other jobs.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Pros to working here include location (Bloomington is great), diversity of activities (influenced by the university), and reputation of graduate programs.
cons: The major cons are its large size, bureaucracy, and politics. However, I don't consider these to be unique to IU. The Greek lifestyle enjoyed by many undergraduates sometimes seems to precede the educational value that students hold. I have many personal cons that I would attribute to being a poor and overworked graduate student in the sciences. However, I feel those are reflective of the more personal setting I am in on a daily basis. My experience at IU as a whole has been wonderful.

pros: There are many opportunities for advancement, and they assist you in furthering your education. Human Resources really wants the employees to be happy, so they offer different half-day sessions to help you with situations that arise in the work place.
cons: A lot of the people that work in management have "education credentials" but no work experience. This can make it a difficult environment to work in when they  don't know anything about computers or technology.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Indiana University provides good pay and opportunities for students, especially when compared to jobs in the community. The academic jobs are incredible as resume builders and help foster relationships with faculty which can be useful later on. Work/Life Balance is fantastic, as supervisors tend to be extremely accommodating with employee's schedules.
cons: HR and its associated bureaucracy can be problematic, I personally experienced a pay delay and had to go through the loop a few times to make sure I received back pay after my first paycheck was skipped. The work is also extremely variable with high turnover rates in the medium to long term.

review_title: Good place to work while going back to school
pros: decent pay.  good work environment.  little stress.  very flexible with time off/working around school schedule.  very good benefits.  overall a good place to work while going back to school or as a first job after graduating
cons: little to no opportunity for promotions and raises.  often have to work alone, so can be kind of boring at times.

pros:
easy, convenient, flexible hours 

bosses are nice, and coworkers are relatively fun. its laid back so its easy to deal with. 

the hours can be set up according to your schedule, even hours for a insomniac, since its 24 hours
cons:
no where to go within the organization. 
its a dead end job
the job is incredibly boring and no one really cares about what you do 
sometimes if your preferred times are not available you could be expected to work at all sorts of random hours and thats never really that much fun. 
bottom line is that this job takes you no where.

review_title: Applicable experience for undergrad work yielding a taste for the field more-so than financial reward.
pros: Very flexible hours as undergraduate laboratory technician. Ability to get a taste for the day-to-day work in field of interest, problem-solve on-the-job, and develop relationships with researchers.
cons: Sometimes only limited hours needed depending upon the needs of the study. Lab work can be tedious.

review_title: Get to retake a class while getting paid
pros: You get paid. It's another opportunity to further enhance your knowledge of the topic. Get exclusive access to a professor and their time. Get the chance to start research. If your resume is lacking, this job will help.
cons: Your mileage may vary. Depends on the professor and the department. Work load varies considerably. You need to demonstrate competence in the subject.  You need to deal with the occasional troubled student who is on the verge of a breakdown . You might get stuck with a professor who offloads all the grading, office hours, etc.

review_title: Love the people I work with; Dislike the pay!
job_title: Faculty Member in South Bend, IN
pros: Collegiality. Working with the students. Lots of opportunity for growth. Support for educators. Training for "best practices". Current technology--or the opportunity to apply for it.
cons: The pay. Arbitrary pay--not fair salary structure or vetting process. Raises not in line with cost of living or merit. New faculty are paid up to 20% MORE than their bosses--departmental chairs, etc... Senority is not rewarded. Better to leave your position for a year, come back and be rehired at the higher rate. {lol}

job_title: Ticket Office Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Plenty of hours during football and basketball season. Don't always have to do the same job at events if you ask to be moved around. Learn to work with other employees and have to sell to customers who are interested. Phone calls are pretty easy as long as you know the right questions to ask and show patience with the older customers.
cons: Some days can be extremely slow and you really do not do anything. Working in the weather isn't always preferable, but the part-time and full-time employees are fun to be around.

pros: Great people, great town, smart folks. I work as a Human Behavior and Energy Consumption teaching assistant. Scheduling is flexible with your schedule.
cons: The town is kind of boring and there are no major roads that lead to Bloomington, making it a pain to travel. It is hard to be motivated to give it your all when you are not interested in what you are working on.

review_title: I loved working at IU Athletics IT
pros:
Awesome people,both coworkers and clients
Working the games means being at all the awesome IU Hoosier games
Great place to learn and expand your skillset
cons:
The pay is low for the IT industry
IT is, obviously, not a focus of the business so often you are asked for miracles with little upper support
Not a ton of places to move up within the department but this is mitigated by opportunities in other IT departments on campus

review_title: Indiana was a great atmosphere and very exciting place to work and Bloomington is a great place to live.
pros: Relaxed work atmosphere, good pay, good hours, good coworkers, enjoyable research work, easy work, great location, very good resources. My experience at Indiana University, at the research position I was at, was very good and I don't have much bad to say about it.
cons: In the position I was at, which was a lab technician for a psychology research laboratory, there was not much room for career opportunities which made this job relatively short-lived because there was very limited opportunity for promotion.

review_title: A Good Balance that helped pay for my grad school
pros: Being an associate instructed helped me pay for my graduate education and teaching the students that cared was rewarding. Working with most professors was good as well
cons: Some challenges to working here are apathetic students who often could care less what they're learning or not. Also the system of clocking in and out is flawed. Hours also varied from week to week and often times you were expected to do more in a week than you were paid for.

review_title: When it's good it's great - when it's bad ...
pros: All comments based upon full time hire into support staff position. Very good health insurance from day one of being hired full time. Accru time off and sick leave from day one of being hired full time. Potential for excellent work / life balance. Potential for a wonderfully supportive atmosphere. Potential to take advantage of a paid college course per semester with full time employment and supervisors approval. Potential for a learning atmosphere. Potential for union help if work issues do arise. Potential for advancement is fairly good.
cons: My experience did not consist of many of the potential benifits. I had 8 supervisors in 4 1/2 years (one did last for a full year). I was denied approval to take advantage of the college course benefit as none fit with my job description. My assigned union rep. was an epic fail.  Massive work loads. When employees leave they were not replaced - remaining employees needed to absorb the added work load, leaving many to do the work of 3 to 4 people. As with anywhere, the management makes or breaks one's experience in the work place. The enviroment in my department was very dysfunctional, clickish and broken. Less and less are positions being promoted. When an employee leaves and the job is reposted, it often is reclassified below the previous standing. The same positions across the university can have wildly  ranging classifications and salary varience. A position in one building that has the same job description and requires all the same skills can range from a low level low hourly wage support staff D level to a high classified, high salary professional level 3.

job_title: Visiting Lecturer in New Albany, IN
pros: Great place to work. Very supportive of junior faculty.
cons:
Very political 
Bad employees, even those that break laws, are allowed to continue with only a slap on the wrist. Instructors that are known to be ineffective, and have been caught plagiarizing and falsifying records are given good faculty awards. The awards and distinctions here mean nothing because of this, except to outsiders.

review_title: Student finds Indiana University a good place to work.
pros: The reason I am working for the University is because I'm currently a student here.  It gives me the opportunity to work at a very fair wage and gain insight into the inner workings of the department of the University that I work for.  The people that I work with are great, and the office environment is very relaxed.  I show up to work in jeans and a t-shirt and that is acceptable because I'm a student employee.  I am also able to set my own hours most days as long as i check with my boss first, which is a huge plus for me.
cons: The position I have is only Summer employment, so I will only have it for the next few months.  The job isn't exactly what I would call exciting, but I do get to be inside and sitting down at a computer most of the time.  Mostly the job is data entry and making copies or assembling materials for seminars.  Though, some days it is just data entry, and 6 consecutive hours of doing data entry can be seriously mind numbing.  Another downside is that none of my co-workers are my age, all of them are significantly older than me, so going out after work with people from the office isn't exactly the best option on a Friday night.

review_title: I am sorry I did not get a PhD from a more prestigious university.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Bloomington, IN
pros: Benefits are good. Bloomington, IN  is inexpensive place to live.
cons: Very unfriendly working environment, very bureaucratic. Faculty politics, prides and vanities are killing all the fun in the academic scientific research. This university is not supporting start-ups and entrepreneurship, actually the opposite. With a PhD in sciences at IUB , after about 200 tenure track applications submitted over 2 years I did not manage to secure an assistant professor position at any of the top-200 USA universities (US NEWS Education top).

pros: I love the educational environment, and I really enjoy working with students. Employees have the same free and low-cost opportunities that students have.
cons: Pay for adjunct faculty is so low that I couldn't even pay the rent on a studio apartment. If this was my only source of income, I would need to live with my parents.

review_title: Each Unit is like a separate company and your milage will vary
pros: Transparent salaries, generous paid time off for professional staff,  good health insurance options, many great co-workers
cons: Raises almost always limited to cost of living, lot of bureaucratic games (especially with central and unit HR)

review_title: You're on your own, for better or worse
pros:
I worked as an associate instructor (AI) while in graduate school. I taught two courses as lead instructor and had almost freedom to do pretty much whatever I wanted (within the bounds of the course description) in each. None of the higher-ups in either program observed any of my classes, which was fine with me at the time, but in hindsight, it would have been good to have the feedback and/or some kind of basis for them to write a reference letter on my behalf. 

As for the pay, no one expects to get paid much for graduate teaching, so on that basis, I have no complaints. You do get health and dental insurance, which is a plus. For many graduate students in the current academic environment, this may be the best you'll ever do, since many adjunct positions do not pay any better and do not even offer benefits.
cons: If you plan to continue in academia after graduate school, you are almost completely on your own when it comes to the job search. There are very few resources in place to help graduate students with this (difficult) process, and it is up to grad students to seek them out on their own. The same goes for teaching-related resources. The Center for Innovative Teaching and Learning (CITL) offers useful advice (seminars, etc.) in each case, but if I hadn't taken it upon myself to enroll in a pedagogy seminar the summer before teaching my first class, I might not have even known about the CITL's existence.

review_title: Great Health Care, Not A Ton of Collaboration
pros: This is a fully resourced department, housing is relatively cheap in the area, and the science is top flight. Plus the health insurance is amazing, basically they pay so much into your HSA that it is will coverage almost all of your deductible.
cons: There is not much in the way of inter-department collaboration or much of a social culture to support post-doc. The managers (P.I.) are very supportive but that doesn't always translate into success. Turnover, in the department service like the sequencing center cause considerable delays for my project in particular.

review_title: nice place to work but lacks prestige
pros: attention paid to work life balance, located in a an easy city to live in, nice coworkers, easy commutes to work, excellent support staff, employees seem valued, excellent gyms and fitness centers on campus
cons: poor personal fit, low national recognition, pay was lower compared to other universities, many students lack motivation for a university setting - university needs to be more selective in who they admit, the strange iu - purdue mix makes politics very wierd

pros:
Flexible hours to work around class schedule.

Great place to learn.

All our clients were under the same roof so it was a little easier to deal with them than in other design jobs.

Overall a wonderful experience.
cons:
Sometimes clients could be a pain to work with but that's to be expected at any job.

Otherwise this was a great job to have while getting an education.

pros: You have access to great support systems, tools and experiences that you might otherwise be unaware of or unable to access as a regular student.
cons: Similar to most jobs, you may miss out of fun opportunities with friends because you have work commitments, but the IU Residential Programs and Services department does work to make your on-the-job time enjoyable.

review_title: It's a great time studying and working here
job_title: Residence Hall Manager in Bloomington, IN
pros: The working hours are flexible. You can customize your own timesheet based on your own schedule. Staff are all kind and willing to give a hand. The management are great. Supervisors are always caring about your feedback.
cons: The benefits for staff should be better. Salary is always hourly based, at the most lowest number. Working environment is good overall, but to some department, the communication inside the teams should be make stronger.

pros: Definitely different than a corporation. It's not cut-throat. It's pretty laid back. Very little outside work required. Basically, people treat you as a human. Also, it's a great university, so it's wonderful being a part of that mission. Great benefits, like time off, medical, etc.
cons: Low pay compared to corporations. Lots of bureaucracy because it's a public institution. Really low yearly raises. High parking cost.

pros:
- fun to teach people
- fun to get to program
- enjoyed trying to make incompetent informatics students value the power of programming because it's extremely challenging.
cons:
- instructor's do not care whether or not students actually learn what they are teaching
- there is zero quality control on the degree
- students have little to no work ethic

review_title: The University works hard, but overworks their workers
job_title: Assistant Guest Services Manager in Bloomington, IN
pros: It's really nice to be able to work at the university that you attend and the minimum wage is higher than it is in the city of Bloomington.
cons: The university makes so much money on tuition and works their student workers too hard. While I understand that the university can't pay much higher, there are a lot of students who are trying to pay for rent and bills and if they work the most hours they can in a week, they likely can't get close with the campus minimum wage.

pros: I started working here as a freshman in college for my work study. All of the admissions staff is so welcoming and friendly. You go though training for a few weeks in the beginning, so you are well prepared for the job. The staff is so understanding when the student employees need to take off work for exams or going home. Best job.
cons: Regardless of performance, you cannot get a raise because its work study. Not really in Admissions control, but still a downside.

pros: Bloomington is a lovely town with lots of wonderful amenities (great parks, restaurants, museums, entertainment venues, and a really great library).
cons: Indiana University, like lots of universities, is heavy on administration (more vice presidents than you can shake a stick at) and change happens slowly.

review_title: Good experience, restriction on tuition exemption
pros: I worked as a language TA. It was good for accumulation of teaching experience, although the workload can easily exceed 20 hours per week.
cons: I thought the tuition exemption for TA applied to all courses, but actually it was strictly within the school you attend. For example, if you are from School of Science and Humanities, tuition exemption doesn't apply to courses offered by School of Education, at least it was this way by May 2014.

pros: Pays well enough to have some extra pocket change.  Hours work with my grad student schedule. Get to learn new skills in the classroom as an instructor.
cons: Sometimes stuck doing the same class over and over again.  Get's tiresome at times. AI's are thrown into classes where they don't have experience.

pros: Benefits, time off, beautiful campus
cons: Believe it or not, there are bully's who are placed in leadership positions. HR will not fight for employees who are struggling with the bully(s) in charge of them.

review_title: department is supportive and there is lots of flexibility with respect to course development
pros: supervisors are helpful and friendly, faculty are generous about sharing resources, I have lots of flexibility to choose/develop texts, assignments, and other materials, and they try to offer me a teaching schedule that works best for me
cons: VAPs aren't included in many faculty meetings and it can be challenging for them to get to know others in the department, as well as the resources available to them. Also, as it is a temporary position, career advice and resources would be greatly appreciated.

review_title: Beware of the "mother-ship" running the show...
pros: Great people, great benefits, large urban campus feel (and convenience).
cons: Managers that restrict promotions based off their opinion, strong emphasis/favoritism on alphabet soup after your name, non-flexible work schedule depending on manager/department, Bloomington controls the show despite not being in touch with needs of regional campuses, be prepared to pay a hefty amount for parking.

pros: Great environment in a midwestern town.  Work with a lot of young people. IU is fun and although the pay isn't really high, the benefits and time off is good.  There is usually flexibility in work schedules.
cons: Parking sometimes difficult.  Work with a lot of young people.  Pay is not as high as private companies.  Difficult to promote. People in management positions get more flexibility than those in entry or staff positions.

review_title: It can be whatever you make it
pros: Nice benefits, beautiful campus, many departments to chose from that can still be related to your field
cons:
Racial and Gender micro aggressions this campus isn't all bad but thinks that its is far more progressive than it actually is

Everything is in a silo, it makes it difficult to connect the dots at times

review_title: Has it's pros and cons... Most of the times Pros out weigh the cons
job_title: Graduate Research & Teaching Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Good work environment and easy to get along with your colleagues. Encouraging and independent work environment.
cons: Very open and free environment. You get the reigns to work on projects and lack of direction might hamper the progress. It is difficult to find the mentor who would take the time to help.

pros: Decent benefits, but does not offer long term disability. Tight knit, friendly colleagues.Teamwork is emphasized.
cons:
Management provides little guidance and insufficient answers to questions. Not accommodating for individuals that may find themselves needing long term disability assistance. Advancement is a rarity. Most employees leave for better paying jobs and more stimulating work. 

It is definitely not easy to find a genuine mentor willing to help students and young/new staff members seeking guidance.

pros: I really liked working for PHIT Lab. Hours were very flexible, and my manager and co-workers were all extremely competent, nice people. You really get out of it what you put in to it.
cons: Weekly meetings didn't have much structure, and kinda felt like you were put on the spot. Not much mentorship, so you have to be 100% autonomous and figure things out for yourself if you want to complete anything.

review_title: A great tech environment to work in!
job_title: Interactive Web Designer in Bloomington, IN
pros: Amazing benefits and vacation. Great technology infrastructure. A lot of talent and very smart and capable people. I would stay for life under the right conditions.
cons: Sometimes slow to adapt, but that is understandable for such a large institution. Task management and team unity for the Kelley School of Business is not working well right now.

pros: You can potentially make quite a bit of money and not be held accountable for anything, or at least that is how it seemed with a wide variety of my coworkers.
cons: Like I said, people were not really held accountable for their work in my job, and that ended up causing a lot of chaos and confusion among different projects.

pros: I split my time between research on an independent project and teaching undergraduate level chemistry courses. It really helped me get a direction in my career path when I realized that teaching was not for me.
cons: The research, although interesting, varied from person to person. There is not a structured set of requirements allowing different people in different groups to graduate with significantly different amount of published work.

review_title: Good opportunity for full time student
pros: It's a great learning experience working in a large (corporate environment). It has prepared me well for the corporate world post college and it has provided me free housing/meal plan/stipend.
cons: Sometimes the hours are not very good and there's a strict guidance from upper management. Also there are strict commitments regarding when to return for winter/summer training.

pros: Great support from supervisors. Encourage creativity, and allow you to express yourself in an environment conducive to development. This is in the Rec Sports department.
cons: The university is very disjointed among departments, which is expected. However, if you want to try different functions it may be hard to network with those people to have a realistic shot at doing so.

review_title: Research Analyst in School of medicine, Indiana University
pros:
Reasonable benefits, 
Onsite day care for kids,
 Tution for continuing education.
Ability to continue to utilize university resources even after you graduate from school.
cons:
Micromanaged by boss (personal experience). Underpaid, Less prospects for growth and development.
Only a temporary place to work if you are in research and development  and you are not a phD

review_title: A Fine Job for a Graduate Student
pros: Almost every professor is easy work with when teaching a course. They understand your work load as a graduate student and often make your teaching job more pleasant.
cons: Teaching a smaller lab class can be bothersome with limited resources to keep up equipment. It was especially difficult working with electronics equipment because many of the components were broken.

review_title: If you work for union board...you get to rule the place. If you're just an hourly worker...get out quick.
job_title: Employee, Maintenance Services in Bloomington, IN
pros: Benefits, PTO, steady paycheck, able to take time off when needed for family happenings.
cons: Bosses don't care about the workers, there is NO training, sense of low work moral, bosses don't care unless you are chapping their backsides.

pros: Relaxed.  Great place to work.  Stay with cutting edge technology.  Limited movement, unless you are a geologist.
cons:
Seems to be some internal strife in the upper management, but it seems to have been cleared up.  Some complaints at the time were about a loss of sense of security.  There has since been a management change.

Pay could be better.  You can earn darn near double in private sector and still do even better in comparable slots within the university.

pros: pay, atmosphere, coworkers, employer support.  It was a great environment to work in, and my supervisor was very encouraging of employees taking on new responsibilities and tasks.  Good hourly rate for the position, as well (although this isn't necessarily true of all jobs).
cons: stressful work situations, many positions strictly part-time.  It would have been nice to have been able to extend a great part-time position into full-time, but that option was not available.

pros: IU fosters an education second to none. I enjoy the opportunity to work with students from all walks of life and use what I've learned throughout life to make a difference in their lives.
cons: Emotions and societal intolerance have become the norm for many young adults and it's been quite a challenge to try and navigate through a plethora of perspectives. It's ok to have opinions students, but they should not be harmful.

review_title: A great town, good school, needs vision
pros: Reasonable cost of living, great students, near Chicago, good colleagues. The city has a lot to offer. It's a good size, friendly, and has most of your basic needs met.
cons: Being a regional campus means we are often an afterthought. The IU system revolves around Bloomington and Indy. Thee needs to be better vision for regional campuses.

pros: benefits are great. lots of time off, free software, great work-life balance.  Overall a good place to work.  One cannot hardly take all of the time off that is accrued annually.
cons: The pay isnt very good at all.  There are plenty of growth/employment opportunities if you are a programmer but not much else otherwise.  They group analyst and programmer into the same category but give much more weight to the programmer part of the job than the analyst.

review_title: Depends widely on the department or unit you work in. Some are easier or harder to get along in.
pros: Stability, benefits, professional development opportunities. Once you are in the door at IU they like to keep you. Many stay for life.
cons: Some folks who stay for life really don't want to be here. Each department or unit varies alot, so be aware when you are interviewing of the personalities. They are not likely to be leaving any time soon, so you'll have to work with them!

pros: The Bio Department has excellent professors that are very willing to collaborate and advise students even if they are not on your committee. There are lots of facilities on campus with lots of helpful support staff including sequencing, computing, microscopy, flow, mass spec, etc. The Department really takes care of their students as far as funding by encouraging grant writing, applying for fellowships and having enough teaching assignments available per semester.
cons: There should be more cross-talk among the programs within Biology.

review_title: Loved being at a big school with big resources and great communication.
job_title: Assistant Research Professor in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
Benefit package - they contribute 10% to 403(b) retirement account, good health insurance (though it went up significantly this year), decent vacation

Good core lab resources - flow cytometry, microarray, sequencing, proteomics, vector, etc

Good internal collaboration

Good focus from administration on research + some internal funding opportunities
cons:
Long work hours (faculty expectation is 55 hrs/wk)

Salary is not great. Equivalent salary for industry is +50% or more.

Long timelines for tenure (7-9 years in IUSM)

pros: Fully paid health care while being paid while working on Master's.  20 hour a week work load is easy to balence with graduate school. The health care benifits can not be beat.  All paid for and really cheap medications and no cost at IU health center.
cons: Not enough Money to pay your bills.  Moderate compensation for 20 hrs per week; however, if you have a car note or any other debts, definately not enough money

pros: On campus, flexible with class schedule, great community to live in and wonderful tuition benefits for FT employees and their families.
cons: Compensation is adequate given the cost of living in Indiana, but still not competitive with Indy positions. The university can be slow to move on some things too.

review_title: Nice place to live and do some research
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Bloomington, IN
pros: It's located in a nice town, there are diverse cultural environments, a good music school so you can get access to free shows, the department of biology has a friendly academic atmosphere, you could balance life and work well.
cons: life could be boring compared to big cities, since there are less activities and attractions. If you want to do quality shopping, you would have to drive 1hr plus. Job opportunities are not as many as bigger cities.

pros: There are plenty of benefits for full time employees and increased wages are happening every year.
cons: There are issues with an exceeding amount of bureaucracy preventing managers from removing troublesome employees as well as administrators that are not held accountable for monetary losses resulting from their actions or in most cases inaction.

pros: Good benefits, perks like PTO.
cons: Current department has arbitrary (poor) leadership, ineffective HR department, advancement opportunities based on alumni status not job performance. Outsiders (those not from the area) are treated differently from locals.  Community is not diverse nor is diversity valued. Very clicky environment.

pros: Supportive Manager and most everyone always pleasant and/or helpful. I worked for this same manager earlier in my career, and she is a good person as well as a good person to work for.
cons: I've worked at the university three times, with only one negative experience. Much  of the day-to-day experience and opportunities in an administrative support staff position is based upon the manager of the department or division where you work. Benefits are good, including healthcare options and 401k.

review_title: A well-rounded experience in undergraduate teaching
pros: Large pool of resources, plenty of technology implementation opportunities, highly involved and dedicated staff, lots of instructional utilities and resources for the classroom
cons: Some classes are too large for 1 instructor, chances for advancement are not always clear, development of career opportunities beyond IU are not readily available

pros: Great benefits, salaries reasonable for residing in Bloomington, IN
cons: I personally had a very poor manager so it is hard to generalize to the entire institution. However, I was offered no assistance (by the administration or anyone else) in seeking another job. Also, the accommodations for disabled persons was poor.

review_title: Good place to work-- lower salaries than most of the Big 10.
pros:
Big University, Bigger Benifits
Lots of people to learn from
Great location
Great Food
Health and Dental insurance for you have assistantship
cons: Depends a lot on who you work what and what you are doing. The people I work with are great, but I have heard of many horror stories, too.

review_title: Lots of great people and challenging work; plenty to learn; low salaries, but great benefits
pros: There are some great people working for IU doing amazing work.  The benefits here can't be beat.  There is plenty of learning and resources for self improvement.
cons: Indiana University gives very low salaries compared to market positions.  Be sure to get everything in writing if there are agreements made at negotiations time.

review_title: Poor quality of management; poor quality of university level leaders
pros: Nice city, nice people, and could be easy if you do not care...
cons: Very poor management by university level leaders or school level leaders. None of them are competitive in their own job. They do not understand research or teaching. They only care about money, money, and money. Labs need updates. Many places, you will see lazy, unrespectful people.

pros: The schedule is flexible and the workload is easy to manage. There are few technical restrictions, and if you're a student the convenience of working on campus is unbeatable.
cons: No managerial support, very isolated work environment, dated professional practices. Compensation is (understandably) low, and colleagues (understandably) are not interested in delivering their very best (I felt a strong sense of disapproval for a job done fast).

job_title: Computer Support Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Working at IU Libraries helped me learn new computing problems in hardware and software. Also troubleshooted with printers which was a whole new experience. Flexible hours adjusted according to my class schedules.
cons: There are no cons of working as a part time here. Although it is sometimes tiring to travel around the whole campus to the different libraries.

review_title: GlobalNOC at IU is a great place to work with a wide diversity of projects at many different levels.
job_title: GlobalNOC Senior Network Engineer in Bloomington, IN
pros:
Great technical exposure and growth.
Wide variety of projects - lots of diverse experience, you aren't pigeon-holed.
Great colleagues - friendly higher ed environment.
